Package dreisoft.tresos.generator.api.generator

Code Generator API This package contains classes that allow to implement a EB tresos Studio code generator via Java Public API.

See: Description

  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    ICodeGenerator Deprecated
    This interface is extended by ICodeGenerator2.
    ICodeGenerator2
    This is the interface that a code generator must implement.
  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    CodeGeneratorContext
    This class represents the interface via which the CodeGenerator framework hands in all relevant data to the generator.
    GeneratorResource
    A GeneratorResource is created via the CodeGeneratorContext to access transparently files stored in cryptocontainers, jar files and or normal files as input resource.
    GeneratorWriter
    This is the implementation of a PrintWriter that should be used to generate files.
    ParameterSet
    Parameters via the generator extension-point.

Package dreisoft.tresos.generator.api.generator Description

Code Generator API

This package contains classes that allow to implement a EB tresos Studio code generator via Java Public API.

Generator Interface

Each code generator must implement the class ICodeGenerator2 and register this implementation via the generator extension-point: 


        <extension
                  point="dreisoft.tresos.generator.api.plugin.generator">
          <generator moduleId="MyModule"
                     id="MyModuleGenerator"
                     class="com.company.MyModuleGenerator">
              <parameter name="MyCustomparameter" value="ParameterValue"/>
          </generator>
        </extension>

The example above registers the class com.company.MyModuleGenerator as the generator. This class implements the ICodeGenerator2 interface: 

        public class MYModuleGenerator implements ICodeGenerator2 {

            /**
             * The mode in which to run the generator by default
             *
             * @return The default mode
             * @since 2008.b
             */
           public String getDefaultMode() {
               return MODE_GENERATE;
           }

           /**
            * The modes in which the generator can run.
            *
            * @since 2008.b
           */
           public String[] getAvailableModes( ParameterSet parameters ) {
               return new String[] { MODE_GENERATE, MODE_VERIFY };
           }

            /**
             * Called to run the generator.
             *
             * @param context parameters for the generator run
             * @since 2008.b
             */
            public void generate( CodeGeneratorContext context ) {
                GeneratorWriter writer = c.getWriter( OUTFILE );
                DCtxt model = c.getDCtxtVariable();
                boolean b = model.var.getBool( "EnableModule" );
                write.printf( "#define EM %s\n", b ? "ON" : "OFF" );
                writer.close();
            }

           /**
            * Unused in this example.
            *
            * @since 12.0
            */
           public void verifySystemModel( CodeGeneratorContext context, APIOperationStatus status ) {
               // a NO-OP here
           }

        } // MYModuleGenerator

Generator Workflow

Multiple generators can be registered for one module. It is even possible to register generators that are not bound to a module. Generators run in three different steps:

  1. Pre: First all pre generators are run. Module independent generators can be registered as pre generators. Module independent pre generators are run before all module dependent pre generators.
  2. Default: After the pre-generators all default generators are run. Default generators are always module dependent.
  3. Post: After all default-generators all post generators are run. Module independent generators can be registered as post generators. Module independent post generators run after all module dependent post generators.

Pre and post generators are marked with the attribute step in the generator extension registration: 


        <extension
                  point="dreisoft.tresos.generator.api.plugin.generator">
          <generator moduleId="MyModule"
                     step="pre"
                     id="MyModulePreGenerator"
                     class="com.company.MyModulePreGenerator">
          </generator>
        </extension>

        <extension
                  point="dreisoft.tresos.generator.api.plugin.generator">
          <generator moduleId="MyModule"
                     step="post"
                     id="MyModulePostGenerator"
                     class="com.company.MyModulePostGenerator">
          </generator>
        </extension>

Module independent generators can be registered by omitting the moduleId attribute from the generator tag.

Generator Modes

Generators can be registered for different generator modes. The most prominent are:

  • generate: Default mode for code generation.
  • verify: Default mode for configuration verification.

but also other modes like a post-build mode or a mode that only generated documentation are imaginable.

The mode in which code generation is run is selected on the commandline:

tresos_cmd.bat generate myproject tresos_cmd.bat verify myproject tresos_cmd.bat make post_build myproject

Each generator can provide support for different modes. The modes in which the generator is called is queried via the method ICodeGenerator2.getAvailableModes(). The mode in which the generator is run

A default mode is returned by ICodeGenerator2.getDefaultMode(). Currently the default mode is never used.

CodeGeneratorContext

The central interface of the generator to the EB tresos Studio is the class CodeGeneratorContext. This class provides all resources to access the generator engine behind the ICodeGenerator2 interface.

The CodeGeneratorContext provides access to:

  • Parameters: The parameters set in the in the extension-point via the parameter tag that apply to the mode in which the generator is currently running.
  • Variables: Variables provides access to paths like the generator output directory, modules that are generated and DCtxts to the project configuration. Variables can be queried and set via the CodeGeneratorContext. Variables that are set via the CodeGeneratorContext are visible to all generators that are run in a later step of the code generation process.
  • GeneratorWriters: the GeneratorWriter is a convenient interface to manage the output of the generator. The GeneratorWriter class is derived from java.io.PrintStream which allows to call C-like methods like printf() to write generator output.
  • GeneratorResources: The GeneratorResource class allows to access files from the plug-in that registered the generator as input transparently hiding if they are encrypted in a crypto container or not.
  • Messages: The CodeGeneratorContext allows to log info, warning and error messages in the form of an APIOperationStatus. If errors are logged the generator process is counted as has been failed by EB tresos Studio.
